chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, folks.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Welcome back.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Hope you had a nice long weekend with no classes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You got caught up on all those problem sets

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that have been sneaking up on you.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You enjoyed watching the Patriots and Tom Brady come

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: back.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Sorry, I'm showing my local bias.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Before we talk about today's topic,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I want to take a second to set the stage.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I want you to stop and think about what you've

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: seen so far in this course.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're coming up on the end of the first section of the course.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you've already seen a lot.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Certainly learned about fundamentals of computation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You've seen different kinds of data structures,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: both immutable and immutable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So tuples and lists, dictionaries,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: different ways of pulling things together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Seen a range of algorithms from simple linear code to loops,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for's and while's.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You've seen iterative algorithms.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You've seen recursive algorithms.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You've seen classes of algorithms.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Divide and conquer, greedy algorithms,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: bisection search, a range of things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then most recently, you saw pulling things together

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with classes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: A way to group together data that belongs together,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: along with methods or procedures that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are designed to manipulate that data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you've had actually a fairly good coverage already

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of a lot of the fundamentals of computation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you're starting to get geared up

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to be able to tackle a pretty interesting range of problems.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Today and Monday, we're going to take a little bit

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of a different look at computation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because now that you've got the tools

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to start building up your own personal armamentarium

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of tools, we'd like to ask a couple of important questions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The primary one of which is, how efficient are my algorithms?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And by efficiency, we'll see it refers both to space and time,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but primarily to time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we'd like to know both how fast are my algorithms going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to run, and how could I reason about that's performance.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's what we're going to do with today's topics.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're going to talk about orders of growth.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We'll define what that means in a few minutes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're going to talk about what's called the big O notation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we're going to begin to explore

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: different classes of algorithms.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Before we do that, though, let's talk about why.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I want to suggest to you there are two reasons

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: this is important to be considering.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: First question is, how could we reason

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: about an algorithm, something you write,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in order to predict how much time is it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to need to solve a problem of a particular size?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I might be testing my code on small scale examples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I want to know if I run it on a really big one,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how long is it going to take?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Can I predict that?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Can I make guesses about how much time I'm going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to need to solve this problem?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Especially if it's in a real world circumstance where

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: time is going to be crucial.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Equally important is going the other direction.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We want you to begin to reason about the algorithms

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to be able to say, how do certain choices

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in the design of an algorithm influence

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how much time it's going to take?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I choose to do this recursively,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is that going to be different than iteratively?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I choose to do this with a particular kind of structure

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in my algorithm, what does that say about the amount of time

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to need?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you're going to see there's a nice association

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: between classes of algorithms and the interior structure

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in particular, we want to ask some fundamental questions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Are there fundamental limits to how much time

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it's going to take to solve a particular problem,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: no matter what kind of algorithm I design around this?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we'll see that there's some nice challenges about that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's what we're going to do over the next two days.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Before we do, though, let's maybe

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: ask the obvious question, why should we care?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Could be on a quiz, might matter to you.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Better choice is because it actually makes a difference.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I say that because it may not

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: be as obvious to you as it was in an earlier generation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So people with my gray hair or what's left of my gray hair

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: like to tell stories.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'll make it short.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But I started programming 41 years ago.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: No, sorry, 45 years ago.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: On punch cards, you don't know what those are unless you've

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: been to a museum, on a machine that filled a half a room

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and that took about five minutes to execute

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what you can do in a fraction of a second on your phone.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is to tell you you're living in a great time,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: not independent of what's going to happen on November 8.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, we'll stay away from those topics as well, won't we?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: My point is, yeah, I tell old stories.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm an old guy.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But you might argue, look, computers

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are getting so much faster.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Does it really matter?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I want to say to you, maybe it's obvious to you, yes,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: absolutely it does.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because in conjunction with us getting faster computers,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we're increasing the sizes of the problems.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The data sets we want to analyze are getting massive.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'll give you an example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I just pulled this off of Google, of course.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In 2014, I don't have more recent numbers.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Google served, I think I have that number right,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: 30 trillion pages on the web.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's either 30 trillion or 30 quadrillion.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I can't count that many zeros there.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It covered 100 million gigabytes of data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I suggest to you, if you want

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to find a piece of information on the web,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can you write a simple little search algorithm that's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to sequentially go through all the pages

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and find anything in any reasonable amount of time?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Probably not, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's just growing way too fast.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This, by the way, is, of course, why Google makes a lot of money

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: off of their MapReduce algorithm for searching the web,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: written by the way, or co-written by an MIT grad

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and the parent of a current MIT student.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So there's a nice hook in there.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Not that Google pays MIT royalties for that wonderful

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: thing, by the way.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, bad jokes aside, searching Google, ton of time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Searching a genomics data set, ton of time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The data sets are growing so fast.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You're working for the US government.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You want to track terrorists using image surveillance

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from around the world, growing incredibly rapidly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Pick a problem that data sets grow so quickly that even

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: if the computers speed up, you still

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: need to think about how do I come up with efficient ways

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to solve those problems?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I want to suggest to you, while sometimes simple solutions

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are great, they're the easy ones to write,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: at times you need to be more sophisticated.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Therefore, we want to reason about how do we

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: measure efficiency and how do we relate algorithm design

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: choices to the cost that's going to be associated with it?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, even when we do that, we've got a choice

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because we could talk about both efficiency in terms of time

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or in terms of space, meaning how much storage

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: do I have inside the computer?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the reason that's relevant is there's actually,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in many cases, a trade-off between those two.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you've actually seen an example,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which you may or may not remember.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You may recall when we introduced dictionaries,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I showed you a variation where you could compute Fibonacci

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: using the dictionary to keep track of intermediate values.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we'll see in next week that it actually tremendously

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: reduces the time complexity.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's called a trade-off in the sense

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that sometimes I can pre-compute portions of the answer,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: store them away so that when I'm trying

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to do a bigger version of the answer,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I can just look up those portions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So there's going to be a trade-off here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're going to focus, for purposes of this lecture

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and the next one, on time efficiency.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: How much time is it going to take our algorithms

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to solve a problem?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, what are the challenges in doing that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: before we look at the actual tools?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in fact, this is going to lead into the tools.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The first one is, even if I've decided on an algorithm,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: there are lots of ways to implement that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: A while loop and a for loop might

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: have slightly different behavior.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I could choose to do it with temporary variables

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or using direct substitution.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Lots of little choices.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So an algorithm could be implemented many different ways.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: How do I measure the actual efficiency of the algorithm?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Second one is, I might, for a given problem,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: have different choices of algorithm.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: A recursive solution versus an iterative one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Using a divide and conquer versus straightforward search.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're going to see some examples of that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I've got to somehow separate those pieces out.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In a particular, I'd like to separate out

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the choice of implementation from the choice of algorithm.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I want to measure how hard is the algorithm, not,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can I come up with a slightly more efficient way of coming up

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with an implementation?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So here are three ways I might do it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we're going to look at each one of them very briefly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The obvious one is we could be scientists.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Time it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Write the code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Run a bunch of test case.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Run a timer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Use that to try and come up with a way of estimating efficiency.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We'll see some challenges with that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Slightly more abstractly, we could count operations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We could say, here are the set of fundamental operations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Mathematical operations, comparisons, setting values,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: retrieving values.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And simply say, how many of those operations

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: do I use in my algorithm as a function

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of the size of the input?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that could be used to give us a sense of efficiency.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're going to see both of those are flawed somewhat more

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in the first case than the second one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And so we're going to abstract that second one

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to a more abstract notion of something

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we call an order of growth.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'll come back to that in a couple of minutes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is the one we're going to focus on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's one that computer scientists use.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It leads to what we call complexity classes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So order of growth or big O notation

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is a way of abstractly describing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the behavior of an algorithm, and especially the equivalences

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of different algorithms.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But let's look at those.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Timing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Python provides a timer for you.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You could import the time module.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you can call.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: As you can see right down here, I

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: find a really simple little function,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: convert Celsius to Fahrenheit.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in particular, I could invoke the clock method

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from the time module.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And what that does is it gives me

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a number as the number of some fractions of a second

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: currently there.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Having done that, I could call the function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then I could call the clock again

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and take the difference to tell me how much time

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it took to execute this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's going to be a tiny amount of time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then I could certainly print out some statistics.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I could do that over a large number of runs,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: different sizes of the input, and come up

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with a sense of how much time does it take.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Here's the problem with that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Not a bad idea.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Again, my goal is to evaluate algorithms.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Do different algorithms have different amounts of time

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: associated with them?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The good news is that if I measure running time,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it will certainly vary as the algorithm changes,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which is what I want to measure.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But one of the problems is that it will also

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: vary as a function of the implementation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I use a loop that's got a couple of more steps inside

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of it in one algorithm than another,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it's going to change the time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I don't really care about that difference.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I'm confounding or conflating implementation influence

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: on time with algorithm influence on time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Not so good.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Worse, timing will depend on the computer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: My Mac here is pretty old.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, at least for computer versions,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it's about five years old.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm sure some of you have much more recent Macs

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or other kinds of machines.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Your speeds may differ from mine.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's not going to help me in trying to measure this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And even if I could measure it on small size problems,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it doesn't necessarily predict what

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: happens when I go to really large size problems

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because of issues like the time it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: takes to get things out of memory

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and bring them back into the computer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what it says is that timing does vary based

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: on what I'd like to measure.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But it varies on a lot of other factors.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's really not all that valuable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, got rid of the first one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's abstract that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: By abstract, I'm going to make the following assumption.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to identify a set of primitive operations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I kind of get to say what they are.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But the obvious one is to say, what does the machine

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: do for me automatically?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That would be things like arithmetic

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or mathematical operations, multiplication, division,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: subtraction, comparisons, something

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: equal to another thing, something greater than,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: something less than, assignments,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: set a name to a value, and retrieval from memory.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to assume that all of these operations

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: take about the same amount of time inside my machine.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The nice thing here is then it doesn't matter

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which machine I'm using.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm measuring how long does the algorithm take

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: by counting how many operations of this type

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are done inside of the algorithm.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm going to use that count to come up

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with a number of operations executed as a function

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of the size of the input.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if I'm lucky, that'll give me a sense of what's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the efficiency of the algorithm.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this one's pretty boring.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's got three steps, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: A multiplication, a division, and an addition.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Four if you count the return.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But if I had a little thing here that added up the integers

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from 0 up to x, I've got a little loop inside here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I could count operations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in this case, it's just, as I said, three operations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Here, I've got one operation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm doing an assignment.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then inside here, in essence,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: there's one operation to set i to a value from that iterator.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Initially, it's going to be 0.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then it's going to be 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you get the idea.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And here, that's actually two operations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's a nice Python shorthand.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But what is that operation?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It says, take the value of total and the value of i,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: add them together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's one operation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then set that value, or rather,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: set the name total to that new value, so second operation.
